title: Scorhill Stone Circle Walking Route

images.title: Derek Harper / Wall by the stroll
images.caption: Wall by the stroll. Trees top the wall beside the stroll leading off the moor at Scorhill Down. The hill in the distance is Cosdon Hill.

images.title: Guy Wareham / Clapper bridge on the North Teign
images.caption: Clapper bridge on the North Teign. This bridge is situated 100 metres upstream from the Teign-e-ver Bridge and 200 metres from the tolmen stone.

images.title: Derek Harper / Path on Scorhill Down
images.caption: Path on Scorhill Down The path is heading towards a footbridge across Gidleigh Leat and then to the Walla Brook and North Teign River, whose valley is ahead.

images.title: Derek Harper / Gidleigh Leat near Scorhill Circle
images.caption: Gidleigh Leat near Scorhill Circle. Looking southeast along the leat with the trees around Batworthy in the background.

images.title: Rob Purvis / View of the river from the clapper bridge, looking east
images.caption: View of the river from the clapper bridge, looking east

images.title: Derek Harper / Lane to Scorhill
images.caption: Lane to Scorhill. The no through lane winds up between trees and scattered housing above Gidleigh. It gives access to Scorhill Down and the upper North Teign valley area of Dartmoor.

images.title: Derek Harper / Field near Scorhill Farm
images.caption: Field near Scorhill Farm

description: This walk visits the Scorhill Stone Circle and the Wallabrook Clapper Bridge in the Teign Valley of Dartmoor. The walk starts from the parking area at Scrohill Farm near Gidleigh. Here you can pick up a footpath along the River Teign Walk and follow it south west up to the stone circle on Scorhill Down. The site is an English Heritage scheduled monument and has been described as Devon's finest, most intact stone circle. It was constructed during the Bronze Age. If you continue a short way along the path you will soon come to the photogenic Wallabrook Clapper Bridge.
